name: How to PoC (for Tanzu Application Platform)

sections.name: intro
sections.title: Introduction
sections.text:
A proof of concept (POC) is the process of proving that an idea is feasible.
It's a screening phase to decide whether the idea can and should be brought to life.
Before proposing a POC, please be aware that it may very well reveal that a great-on-paper proposal doesn't have legs to stand on

contents.title: Customers’ high level objectives
contents.text: Evaluate VMware Tanzu Kubernetes for Operations (TKO) offering from Administration, DevOps and Platform perspectives.

contents.title: VMware Tanzu objectives
contents.text:
The goal of a PoC is not to provide an exhaustive vetting of every capability of TKO. If a customer asks for this, they are likely in exploratory mode, not purchasing mode. 
A PoC should be used to validate a subset of platform capabilities that address an immediate need for thecustomer and that can justify the execution of an initialsale. We should educate and enable the customer on other platform features that don’t fall in this scope but not in the context of a formal PoC.

contents.title: Identify and validate with customer TAP Evaluation Points (Use cases)
contents.text:
In order to identifying use cases for the PoC, meet the customer to discover challenges on application modernization.
With these feedbacks, create a proof of concept of the product that addresses the pain points and offers feasible solutions. It is necessary to detail the product development components, including clearly defined success criteria, functionalities, features and benefits of the product

contents.title: Knowledge Transfer
contents.text: In order to allow customer to become confident and understand Tanzu value, a knowledge transfer activity should be planned. This activity enables organisations within the customer to acquire expertise, skills, and experience on PoC’s involved technologies.

contents.title: Show Outcomes
contents.subtitle: Presentation of the proof of concept outcomes
contents.text: The finalised proof of concept will then be presented to stakeholders and investors for their approval, certifying its viability and finally approving the product for development. This should clarify, among other things, the problems solved by the product, the features addressed by these solutions and the technologies integrated in its development to demonstrate the feasibility of the project idea. It is also necessary to include details such as schedule, cost, success criteria and resources
